messages.content:
List of genes : <<< CNDP1,ALDH3B2,AOC3,AOC2,HIBCH,CSAD,DPYS,ALDH3B1,GAD1,ALDH2,ACOX3,GADL1,ALDH3A2,ALDH9A1,MLYCD,ALDH6A1,HADHA,EHHADH,UPB1,ACOX1,CARNS1 >>>
List of compounds : <<< D-4'-Phosphopantothenate,Spermine,beta-Nitropropanoate,Uracil,4-Aminobutyraldehyde,Spermidine,beta-Alanine,Malonyl-CoA,Propenoyl-CoA,Propynoate,beta-Alanyl-L-arginine,3-Aminopropanal,3-Hydroxypropanoate,L-Aspartate,beta-Alanyl-CoA,4-Aminobutanoate,N-Acetyl-beta-alanine,Malonate,5,6-Dihydrouracil,3-Aminopropiononitrile,Propanoyl-CoA,Acetyl-CoA,Pantothenate,Quinolinate >>>

The metabolic pathway identified in this experiment is "beta-Alanine metabolism". This conclusion is supported by the alteration of several genes and compounds directly involved in this pathway. The genes CNDP1, DPYS, GAD1, GADL1, MLYCD, and EHHADH, which are known to participate in beta-alanine metabolism, were found to be altered. Additionally, the compounds beta-Alanine, beta-Alanyl-L-arginine, beta-Alanyl-CoA, N-Acetyl-beta-alanine, and Propanoyl-CoA, which are key intermediates in this pathway, were also altered. The alterations in these genes and compounds suggest that the beta-Alanine metabolism pathway is implicated in the condition studied.

List of genes : <<< PLA2G4E,PLA2G2D,FADS2 >>>
List of compounds : <<< 3,6-Nonadienal,trans-2-Enoyl-OPC4-CoA,Etherolenic acid,(+)-7-Isomethyljasmonate,OPC6-CoA,trans-2-Enoyl-OPC6-CoA,Colnelenic acid,Stearidonic acid,Traumatic acid,(-)-Jasmonic acid,Phosphatidylcholine,9-Hydroxy-12-oxo-15(Z)-octadecenoic acid,2(R)-HOT,(9Z,12Z,15Z)-Octadecatrienoic acid,9(S)-HPOT,2(R)-HPOT,(+)-7-Isojasmonic acid,10-OPDA,trans-2-Enoyl-OPC8-CoA,9,10-EOT,(3Z)-Hex-3-en-1-yl acetate,9(S)-HOT,3-Oxo-OPC4-CoA >>>

The metabolic pathway identified in the comparison of the two conditions is the alpha-Linolenic acid metabolism. This pathway was implicated due to the alterations in several key genes and compounds. The genes PLA2G4E and PLA2G2D are involved in the hydrolysis of phospholipids, which can release alpha-linolenic acid. The gene FADS2 encodes for an enzyme that plays a role in the desaturation of fatty acids, including alpha-linolenic acid. The presence of compounds such as Stearidonic acid, Traumatic acid, and 9,12,15-Octadecatrienoic acid, which are intermediates in the alpha-Linolenic acid metabolism, further supports this conclusion. Additionally, the identification of compounds like 10-OPDA, a key signaling molecule derived from alpha-linolenic acid, and Jasmonic acid, a hormone derived from alpha-Linolenic acid, further strengthens the association of this pathway with the condition.

List of genes : <<< TXNRD2,SEPSECS,KYAT1,PAPSS1,TXNRD3,TXNRD1,MTR,INMT,MARS2,SEPHS1 >>>
List of compounds : <<< Selenohomocysteine,Methaneselenol,gamma-Glutamyl-Se-methylselenocysteine,Methylselenopyruvate,L-Selenocysteine,Adenylylselenate,O-Phosphoseryl-tRNA(Sec),Methylselenic acid,Methylselenocysteine Se-oxide,Trimethylselenonium,L-Alanine,Selenite,Se-Methyl-L-selenocysteine,L-Seryl-tRNA(Sec) >>>

The metabolic pathway identified in this experiment is Selenocompound metabolism. This conclusion is supported by the alterations observed in multiple genes and compounds associated with this pathway. The genes TXNRD1, TXNRD2, TXNRD3, MTR, and SEPHS1 are involved in selenium metabolism, while KYAT1, SEPSECS, and MARS2 are involved in the biosynthesis of selenoproteins. The observed changes in these genes suggest a disturbance in selenocompound metabolism. The altered compounds, including Selenohomocysteine, Methaneselenol, gamma-Glutamyl-Se-methylselenocysteine, Methylselenopyruvate, L-Selenocysteine, Adenylylselenate, O-Phosphoseryl-tRNA(Sec), Methylselenic acid, Methylselenocysteine Se-oxide, Trimethylselenonium, L-Alanine, Selenite, Se-Methyl-L-selenocysteine, and L-Seryl-tRNA(Sec), are all products or intermediates of selenocompound metabolism, further supporting the involvement of this pathway.

List of genes : <<< ENPP3,NT5C,ENTPD1,NUDT2,RRM2B,ENTPD6,CDA,NT5E,NT5C2,UPB1 >>>
List of compounds : <<< CDP,Uridine,UDP,5,6-Dihydrouracil,dTMP >>>

The metabolic pathway identified in the experiment is Pyrimidine metabolism. This pathway was found to be involved based on the alterations in the genes ENPP3, NT5C, ENTPD1, NUDT2, RRM2B, ENTPD6, CDA, NT5E, NT5C2, and UPB1, all of which are associated with pyrimidine metabolism. Additionally, changes were observed in several pyrimidine-related compounds such as CDP, Uridine, UDP, 5,6-Dihydrouracil, and dTMP. These gene and compound alterations suggest modifications in the synthesis, degradation, and salvage of pyrimidine nucleotides, which are crucial for DNA and RNA synthesis. Therefore, the Pyrimidine metabolism pathway appears to be implicated in the observed condition.

List of genes : <<< GALNT12,GALNT15,ST6GALNAC4,GALNT3,GALNT14 >>>
List of compounds : <<< [Protein]-L-serine,UDP-N-acetyl-D-galactosamine,Tn antigen,T antigen,Sialyl-Tn antigen >>>

The metabolic pathway identified in the experiment is the Mucin type O-glycan biosynthesis. This pathway was implicated due to the alterations observed in several genes and compounds directly involved in this process. The genes GALNT12, GALNT15, ST6GALNAC4, GALNT3, and GALNT14 are all responsible for the initiation and elongation of O-glycan chains in mucin proteins. The altered compounds, including [Protein]-L-serine, UDP-N-acetyl-D-galactosamine, Tn antigen, T antigen, and Sialyl-Tn antigen, are key substrates and products in this pathway. The Tn and T antigens are truncated O-glycans, and the Sialyl-Tn antigen is a sialylated form of the Tn antigen, all indicating disruptions in the O-glycan biosynthesis pathway. Therefore, the changes in these genes and compounds strongly suggest that the Mucin type O-glycan biosynthesis pathway is involved in the observed condition.

List of genes : <<< CS,SUCLA2,PDHA2,ACO2,OGDHL,IDH2,SDHC,DLST,ACLY,SUCLG1,ACO1,IDH3A,MDH2 >>>
List of compounds : <<< 2-Oxoglutarate,Citrate,Enzyme N6-(lipoyl)lysine,Enzyme N6-(dihydrolipoyl)lysine,Succinate,Fumarate,Acetyl-CoA,Enzyme N6-(lipoyl)lysine,Thiamin diphosphate,[Dihydrolipoyllysine-residue acetyltransferase] S-acetyldihydrolipoyllysine,Isocitrate,3-Carboxy-1-hydroxypropyl-ThPP,Oxaloacetate,Phosphoenolpyruvate,Oxalosuccinate,[Dihydrolipoyllysine-residue succinyltransferase] S-succinyldihydrolipoyllysine,Pyruvate,Succinyl-CoA >>>

The metabolic pathway identified in this experiment is the Citrate Cycle (TCA Cycle). This conclusion is supported by the alteration of multiple genes and compounds associated with this pathway. Genes such as CS, SUCLA2, PDHA2, ACO2, OGDHL, IDH2, SDHC, DLST, ACLY, SUCLG1, ACO1, IDH3A, and MDH2 are all involved in the TCA Cycle. Similarly, the altered compounds, including 2-Oxoglutarate, Citrate, Enzyme N6-(lipoyl)lysine, Enzyme N6-(dihydrolipoyl)lysine, Succinate, Fumarate, Acetyl-CoA, Thiamin diphosphate, [Dihydrolipoyllysine-residue acetyltransferase] S-acetyldihydrolipoyllysine, Isocitrate, 3-Carboxy-1-hydroxypropyl-ThPP, Oxaloacetate, Phosphoenolpyruvate, Oxalosuccinate, [Dihydrolipoyllysine-residue succinyltransferase] S-succinyldihydrolipoyllysine, Pyruvate, and Succinyl-CoA, are all intermediates or cofactors in the TCA Cycle. Therefore, the data suggest that the TCA Cycle is significantly affected in the given conditions.

List of genes : <<< SELENOI,PCYT1A,CEPT1,CHPT1,PCYT1B,PCYT2 >>>
List of compounds : <<< Pyruvate,Phosphonoacetate,Diacylglyceryl-2-aminoethylphosphonate,Hydroxymethylphosphonate,Methylphosphonate,Diacylglyceryl-N-trimethyl-2-aminoethylphosphonate,D-Ribose 5-phosphate,N-Trimethyl-2-aminoethylphosphonate,Demethylphosphinothricin,2-Amino-3-phosphonopropanoate,Bialaphos,Phosphonoacetaldehyde,Rhizocticin C,2-Phosphinomethylmalate,2-Acetamidoethylphosphonate,Phosphonoformate,Rhizocticin A,CMP-2-aminoethylphosphonate >>>

In the experiment comparing two conditions, the identified metabolic pathway was the Phosphonate and phosphinate metabolism. This conclusion is based on the significantly altered genes and compounds associated with this pathway. The genes SELENOI, PCYT1A, CEPT1, CHPT1, PCYT1B, and PCYT2 are involved in the regulation of phospholipid metabolism, which is closely related to phosphonate and phosphinate metabolism.

The presence of numerous phosphonate and phosphinate compounds such as Pyruvate, Phosphonoacetate, Diacylglyceryl-2-aminoethylphosphonate, Hydroxymethylphosphonate, Methylphosphonate, and others, further supports the involvement of this pathway. These compounds are key intermediates or products of the phosphonate and phosphinate metabolism. Therefore, the alteration in these genes and compounds strongly suggests that the Phosphonate and phosphinate metabolism pathway plays a crucial role in the studied condition.

List of genes : <<< ENO3,SDSL,AMT,ADH5 >>>
List of compounds : <<< D-Ribulose 5-phosphate,2-(Methylthio)ethanesulfonate,5-Formyl-5,6,7,8-tetrahydromethanopterin >>>

The experiment identified the Carbon metabolism pathway as being significantly altered. The genes ENO3, involved in glycolysis, and ADH5, involved in ethanol metabolism, provide a direct link to carbon metabolism. The alteration in these genes could affect the conversion of glucose to pyruvate and the conversion of acetaldehyde to ethanol, respectively. The compound D-Ribulose 5-phosphate, a key intermediate in the Calvin cycle and pentose phosphate pathway, further supports this. The presence of 5-Formyl-5,6,7,8-tetrahydromethanopterin, a cofactor in the methanogenesis pathway, suggests a possible link to carbon metabolism through the methane cycle. The altered gene SDSL, involved in sulfur metabolism, could be linked to carbon metabolism through the assimilation of sulfur into organic compounds.

List of genes : <<< PGM2,UGDH,CMAS,UXS1,GFPT1,MIOX,GMDS,GMPPA,UGP2,TGDS,HK2,GALK1,GALE,PGM3,HK1,NANP,UAP1L1,HK3,GNE,PGM1,GFPT2,FCSK,MPI >>>
List of compounds : <<< UDP-alpha-D-galactose,3-Deoxy-D-glycero-D-galacto-non-2-ulopyranosonate 9-phosphate,dTDP-4-oxo-6-deoxy-D-glucose,UDP-N-acetyl-3-(1-carboxyvinyl)-D-glucosamine,UDP-alpha-D-galactofuranose,dTDP-4-amino-4,6-dideoxy-D-galactose,UDP-D-galacturonate,UDP-N-acetyl-D-galactosamine,alpha-D-Glucosamine 1-phosphate >>>

The metabolic pathway identified in the experiment is the Biosynthesis of nucleotide sugars. This pathway was implicated due to the alterations in multiple genes and compounds associated with this pathway. The genes PGM2, UGDH, CMAS, UXS1, GFPT1, GMPPA, UGP2, TGDS, GALE, GFPT2, and GNE are all involved in the biosynthesis of nucleotide sugars. Similarly, the compounds UDP-alpha-D-galactose, 3-Deoxy-D-glycero-D-galacto-non-2-ulopyranosonate 9-phosphate, dTDP-4-oxo-6-deoxy-D-glucose, UDP-N-acetyl-3-(1-carboxyvinyl)-D-glucosamine, UDP-alpha-D-galactofuranose, dTDP-4-amino-4,6-dideoxy-D-galactose, UDP-D-galacturonate, UDP-N-acetyl-D-galactosamine, and alpha-D-Glucosamine 1-phosphate are intermediates or products of this pathway. Therefore, the alterations in these genes and compounds strongly suggest that the Biosynthesis of nucleotide sugars pathway is involved in the condition under investigation.

List of genes : <<< TST,SQOR,PAPSS2,SUOX,SELENBP1,BPNT2 >>>
List of compounds : <<< Hydrogen sulfide,Adenosine 3',5'-bisphosphate,Sulfite,S-Sulfanylglutathione,Thiosulfate,Sulfate,Dimethyl sulfide,Trithionate,Sulfate,Dimethyl sulfoxide,Thiosulfate >>>

The metabolic pathway identified in the experiment is Sulfur Metabolism. This pathway was implicated due to the alterations in various genes and compounds associated with sulfur metabolism. The genes TST, SQOR, PAPSS2, SUOX, SELENBP1, and BPNT2 are all involved in different steps of this pathway. TST and SUOX are involved in the oxidation of sulfite to sulfate, while SQOR participates in the oxidation of sulfide to sulfite. PAPSS2 is responsible for the activation of sulfate to adenosine 3',5'-bisphosphate, a key intermediate in sulfate metabolism. SELENBP1 and BPNT2 are also involved in sulfur metabolism, specifically in the regulation of sulfur-containing compounds. The altered compounds, including hydrogen sulfide, sulfite, S-Sulfanylglutathione, thiosulfate, sulfate, dimethyl sulfide, trithionate, and dimethyl sulfoxide, are all intermediates or end products in the sulfur metabolism pathway. Therefore, the changes in these genes and compounds strongly suggest that the Sulfur Metabolism pathway is involved in the condition under investigation.

List of genes : <<< BCKDHB,MMUT,SUCLG1,ACSS1,MLYCD,LDHA,EHHADH >>>
List of compounds : <<< (S)-Lactaldehyde,Propanal,Methylglyoxal,Thiamin diphosphate,Enzyme N6-(dihydrolipoyl)lysine,beta-Alanyl-CoA,2-Hydroxybutanoic acid,Lactoyl-CoA,(S)-Lactate,Propane-1-ol,Propanoyl phosphate,Hydroxyacetone,Propionyladenylate,Acrylic acid >>>

The metabolic pathway identified in this experiment is Propanoate metabolism. Several genes involved in this pathway were altered, including BCKDHB, MLYCD, and LDHA. These genes encode enzymes that play crucial roles in the metabolism of propionyl-CoA, a key intermediate in the Propanoate metabolism. The alteration of these genes likely impacted the conversion of propionyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA, a process necessary for the proper functioning of this pathway. Additionally, the altered compounds such as (S)-Lactaldehyde, Propanal, Propionyladenylate, and (S)-Lactate are also associated with this pathway, further supporting the involvement of Propanoate metabolism in the observed condition.

List of genes : <<< RGN,PFKP,PGM2,DERA,FBP2,ALDOA,PRPS2,ALDOB,GPI,RPIA,PRPS1L1,PGD,ALDOC,FBP1,PFKM,PGLS,SHPK,G6PD,PRPS1,PGM1 >>>
List of compounds : <<< 6-Phospho-2-dehydro-D-gluconate,D-Erythrose 4-phosphate,D-Ribulose 1,5-bisphosphate,Deoxyribose,alpha-D-Glucose 6-phosphate,D-Glucose,3-Phospho-D-glycerate,beta-D-Glucose 6-phosphate,D-Ribose 5-phosphate,D-Glucono-1,5-lactone,D-Glycerate,2-Deoxy-D-ribose 1-phosphate,2-Dehydro-3-deoxy-6-phospho-D-gluconate,D-arabino-Hex-3-ulose 6-phosphate,2-Amino-2-deoxy-D-gluconate,6-Phospho-D-gluconate,alpha-D-Ribose 1-phosphate >>>

The metabolic pathway identified in the experiment is the Pentose Phosphate Pathway (PPP). This pathway was deduced from the alterations in multiple genes and compounds. The genes involved, such as G6PD, PGD, and PGLS, are key enzymes in the PPP, which is responsible for the synthesis of ribose-5-phosphate and NADPH. The altered compounds, including D-Glucose 6-phosphate, D-Ribose 5-phosphate, and D-Erythrose 4-phosphate, are intermediates in the PPP, further supporting the identification of this pathway. The changes in these genes and compounds suggest an increased flux through the PPP, potentially due to an increased demand for nucleotides or NADPH, or a decreased demand for glycolytic intermediates.

List of genes : <<< HADH,ELOVL3,HACD3,ACOT4,THEM4,ELOVL1,HACD4 >>>
List of compounds : <<< Very-long-chain acyl-CoA,2-trans-Dodecenoyl-CoA,Long-chain acyl-CoA,Acyl-CoA,Tetradecanoyl-CoA,Palmitoyl-CoA,3-Oxotetradecanoyl-CoA,Very-long-chain (3R)-3-hydroxyacyl-CoA,Acetyl-CoA,(S)-3-Hydroxytetradecanoyl-CoA,3-Oxoacyl-CoA,Octanoyl-CoA,Very-long-chain acyl-CoA,Palmitoyl-CoA,Acyl-CoA,(S)-3-Hydroxydodecanoyl-CoA,Decanoyl-CoA,trans-Hexadec-2-enoyl-CoA,trans-Hex-2-enoyl-CoA >>>

The metabolic pathway identified in this experiment is fatty acid elongation. This conclusion is supported by the altered genes and compounds observed. The genes HADH, ELOVL3, HACD3, HACD4, and ELOVL1 are all known to be involved in fatty acid elongation. ELOVL3 and ELOVL1, for instance, encode elongases that are responsible for the elongation of very-long-chain fatty acids, which is consistent with the presence of very-long-chain acyl-CoA and very-long-chain (3R)-3-hydroxyacyl-CoA in the list of compounds. Similarly, HADH, HACD3, and HACD4 are involved in the oxidation and desaturation of long-chain fatty acids, which explains the presence of compounds such as 2-trans-Dodecenoyl-CoA, 3-Oxotetradecanoyl-CoA, and (S)-3-Hydroxytetradecanoyl-CoA. The alteration of ACOT4 and THEM4, which are involved in fatty acid beta-oxidation and fatty acid activation, respectively, further supports the involvement of the fatty acid elongation pathway in the observed condition.

List of genes : <<< SIRT5,ENPP1,SIRT1,NT5C1A,QPRT,SIRT2,NMNAT2,NT5C1B-RDH14,NADK,NUDT12,NT5M,BST1,NT5C1B,NT5C >>>
List of compounds : <<< Fumarate,Nicotinurate,L-Aspartate,Pyruvate,2,5-Dihydroxypyridine,Maleic acid,Maleamate,Nicotinamide,2-Methyleneglutarate,Deamino-NAD+,2,6-Dihydroxy-N-methylmyosmine,3,3'-Bipyridine-2,2',5,5',6,6'-hexol,Nicotinate,(S)-2-(Hydroxymethyl)glutarate,Nicotinamide D-ribonucleotide,2,3-Dimethylmaleate,Pseudooxynicotine >>>

The metabolic pathway identified in this experiment is Nicotinate and nicotinamide metabolism. This conclusion is supported by the alterations observed in several genes and compounds related to this pathway. For instance, the genes SIRT1, SIRT2, and NMNAT2 are known to be involved in nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) metabolism, which is a key component of this pathway. Additionally, the compounds nicotinurate, nicotinamide, nicotinate, and NAD+ derivatives like Deamino-NAD+ and Nicotinamide D-ribonucleotide, were also altered, further bolstering the identification of this pathway. These findings suggest that changes in Nicotinate and nicotinamide metabolism may be associated with the observed condition.

List of genes : <<< ALPI,TPK1,NFS1,NTPCR,ALPL,AK1,AK5,AK8,AK2,AK7 >>>
List of compounds : <<< [Enzyme]-S-sulfanylcysteine,Sulfur-carrier protein,L-Cysteine,L-Tyrosine,ADP-5-ethyl-4-methylthiazole-2-carboxylate,Pyridoxal phosphate,4-Amino-5-hydroxymethyl-2-methylpyrimidine diphosphate,Adenylyl-[sulfur-carrier protein],Pyruvate,Thiamin triphosphate,Aminoimidazole ribotide,[Enzyme]-cysteine >>>

The metabolic pathway identified in the experiment is Thiamine metabolism. This pathway was inferred due to the alterations in several genes and compounds directly related to it. The genes ALPI, ALPL, and AK family members (AK1, AK5, AK8, AK2, AK7) are involved in enzymatic reactions requiring cofactors such as Thiamine pyrophosphate (ThPP), the active form of Thiamine. The compounds Thiamin triphosphate, Pyridoxal phosphate, Adenylyl-[sulfur-carrier protein], and [Enzyme]-S-sulfanylcysteine are all intermediates or cofactors in the Thiamine metabolism pathway. Furthermore, the presence of compounds like L-Cysteine and Sulfur-carrier protein suggest involvement of sulfur metabolism, which overlaps with Thiamine metabolism. The alterations in these genes and compounds therefore point towards the Thiamine metabolism pathway being implicated in the observed condition.

List of genes : <<< DHFR2,UGT2B28,HAAO,GPHN,DHRS3,GCLC,ALDH2,AKR1A1,PHOSPHO2,AK5,TPK1,MOCS2,UGT2B17,NME1-NME2,RFK,ADSL,AK1,COQ5,UGT2A1,NADK2,PANK3,MTHFD1,UGT1A10 >>>
List of compounds : <<< Dehypoxanthine futalosine,Cobalt-precorrin 5A,gamma-L-Glutamyl-L-cysteine,Dihydrolipoylprotein,Coenzyme F420-1,8-Amino-7-oxononanoate,4-Amino-5-hydroxymethyl-2-methylpyrimidine diphosphate,Chorismate,5,6,7,8-Tetrahydromethanopterin,Pimelate,3-Demethylubiquinol,Uroporphyrinogen III,Homogentisate,3-Aminopropanal,Nickel-sirohydrochlorin a,c-diamide >>>

The altered genes and compounds in this experiment suggest that the metabolic pathway involved is the Biosynthesis of Cofactors. Several genes such as GCLC, COQ5, and MTHFD1 are involved in the production of cofactors like glutathione, CoQ10, and folate, respectively. The presence of compounds such as Cobalt-precorrin 5A, Coenzyme F420-1, and Nickel-sirohydrochlorin a, which are intermediates or final products in cofactor biosynthesis, further supports this. Additionally, the alteration in genes like DHFR2, ALDH2, and AK1, which are involved in redox reactions utilizing cofactors, also indicates a direct link to this pathway.

List of genes : <<< ALDH3A2,IVD,OXCT2,ALDH1B1,ALDH7A1,ALDH9A1,MCEE,EHHADH >>>
List of compounds : <<< [Dihydrolipoyllysine-residue (2-methylpropanoyl)transferase] S-(2-methylbutanoyl)dihydrolipoyllysine,3-Methyl-2-oxobutanoic acid,(S)-2-Methylbutanoyl-CoA,(S)-3-Hydroxyisobutyrate,2-Methylbut-2-enoyl-CoA,(S)-Methylmalonyl-CoA,Acetoacetyl-CoA,Enzyme N6-(dihydrolipoyl)lysine,(S)-3-Hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl-CoA,3-Methyl-1-hydroxybutyl-ThPP,Acetoacetate,3-Methylbutanoyl-CoA,L-Leucine,Acetyl-CoA,(2S,3S)-3-Hydroxy-2-methylbutanoyl-CoA,(S)-3-Methyl-2-oxopentanoic acid,[Dihydrolipoyllysine-residue (2-methylpropanoyl)transferase] S-(3-methylbutanoyl)dihydrolipoyllysine,Thiamin diphosphate,2-Methylprop-2-enoyl-CoA,Succinyl-CoA,Methylmalonate >>>

The metabolic pathway identified in this experiment is Valine, Leucine, and Isoleucine Degradation. This pathway was identified due to the alterations in genes such as ALDH3A2, ALDH1B1, ALDH7A1, and ALDH9A1, which are involved in the degradation of branched-chain amino acids. The presence of compounds like L-Leucine, (S)-3-Methyl-2-oxobutanoic acid, and (S)-3-Methyl-2-oxopentanoic acid, which are intermediates in this pathway, further supports this identification. Additionally, the alteration in compounds like Acetoacetyl-CoA and Acetoacetate, which are end products of this pathway, provides further evidence. Therefore, the data suggests that this pathway is significantly affected in the given condition.

List of genes : <<< PDHA1,ENO2,ADH5,G6PC2,PGAM2,ADH4,ENO3,ALDH1B1,ADH1B,ADH1A,PGM2,PGAM1,PFKM,DLD,PDHA2,GAPDHS,PGM1 >>>
List of compounds : <<< 2-Phospho-D-glycerate,D-Fructose 1,6-bisphosphate,3-Phospho-D-glycerate,Phosphoenolpyruvate,Pyruvate,beta-D-Glucose 6-phosphate,D-Glucose 1-phosphate,[Dihydrolipoyllysine-residue acetyltransferase] S-acetyldihydrolipoyllysine,alpha-D-Glucose,D-Fructose 6-phosphate,Glycerone phosphate,Salicin,Acetaldehyde,Oxaloacetate,2-(alpha-Hydroxyethyl)thiamine diphosphate,Acetate >>>

The metabolic pathway identified from the experiment is Glycolysis / Gluconeogenesis. This pathway was indicated by the alterations in multiple genes and compounds involved in this metabolic process. The genes PDHA1, ENO2, PGAM2, PGM2, PFKM, and GAPDHS are all directly associated with glycolysis, while G6PC2 and PGM1 are involved in gluconeogenesis. The compounds 2-Phospho-D-glycerate, D-Fructose 1,6-bisphosphate, 3-Phospho-D-glycerate, Phosphoenolpyruvate, Pyruvate, D-Glucose 6-phosphate, D-Glucose 1-phosphate, and Glycerone phosphate are all intermediates in this pathway. Furthermore, the presence of Acetaldehyde and Acetate suggests involvement of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex, which connects glycolysis to the citric acid cycle. Therefore, the data strongly suggests that Glycolysis / Gluconeogenesis is the affected metabolic pathway.

List of genes : <<< PKM,PKLR,PGLS,ENO2,AGXT,CS,GLUD1,GPT2,ALDOA,RGN,PSPH,PFKL,HAO2,CPS1,ALDOC,ACSS2,IDNK,IDH3A,HK1,RPIA,PRPS2,SUCLA2,SUCLG2,OGDHL,MDH2 >>>
List of compounds : <<< D-Glucono-1,5-lactone 6-phosphate,5,10-Methylenetetrahydrofolate,2-Methylfumaryl-CoA,alpha-D-Glucose 6-phosphate,Glycerone,Acetoacetyl-CoA,(3S)-Citryl-CoA,5-Methyltetrahydrofolate,D-Erythrose 4-phosphate,Tetrahydrofolate >>>

The metabolic pathway identified in this experiment is carbon metabolism. This pathway was implicated due to the alterations in genes and compounds associated with it. The genes PKM, PKLR, PGLS, ENO2, CS, GLUD1, GPT2, ALDOA, RGN, PSPH, PFKL, HK1, RPIA, PRPS2, SUCLA2, SUCLG2, and OGDHL are all involved in various aspects of carbon metabolism, including glycolysis, gluconeogenesis, the citric acid cycle, and the pentose phosphate pathway. The altered compounds, such as D-Glucono-1,5-lactone 6-phosphate, alpha-D-Glucose 6-phosphate, D-Erythrose 4-phosphate, and Acetoacetyl-CoA, are intermediates or products of these pathways. Therefore, the changes in these genes and compounds suggest that carbon metabolism is significantly affected in the condition being studied.

List of genes : <<< ELOVL6,HACD3,ELOVL2,ECHS1,ELOVL3,PPT2,ACOT2,TECR,ACOT7,MECR,ACAA2,THEM4,ACOT4 >>>
List of compounds : <<< Very-long-chain acyl-CoA,trans-2,3-Dehydroacyl-CoA,Very-long-chain trans-2,3-dehydroacyl-CoA,(S)-3-Hydroxyhexadecanoyl-CoA,(S)-3-Hydroxydodecanoyl-CoA,Hexanoyl-CoA,3-Oxododecanoyl-CoA,Hexadecanoic acid,Palmitoyl-CoA,3-Oxoacyl-CoA,Acyl-CoA,trans-Tetradec-2-enoyl-CoA,trans-Oct-2-enoyl-CoA,Long-chain fatty acid,Decanoyl-CoA,Very-long-chain 3-oxoacyl-CoA,Fatty acid,trans-Hex-2-enoyl-CoA,Palmitoyl-CoA,Acyl-CoA,Hexadecanoic acid,trans-Hexadec-2-enoyl-CoA,Very-long-chain acyl-CoA >>>

The metabolic pathway identified in the experiment is fatty acid elongation. This fits with the altered genes and compounds as several genes involved in this pathway were affected, including ELOVL6, ELOVL2, ELOVL3, ECHS1, and TECR. These genes are known to be involved in the elongation of very-long-chain fatty acids, which is consistent with the increased levels of very-long-chain acyl-CoA and very-long-chain 3-oxoacyl-CoA observed in the experiment. Additionally, the presence of trans-2,3-Dehydroacyl-CoA and Very-long-chain trans-2,3-dehydroacyl-CoA further supports the involvement of fatty acid elongation, as these compounds are intermediates in the elongation process. Overall, the data suggest that the fatty acid elongation pathway is altered in the condition being studied.

The metabolic pathway identified from the given data is the "Biosynthesis of unsaturated fatty acids". This conclusion is drawn based on the altered genes and compounds. The genes listed, such as ELOVL1, ELOVL5, ELOVL6, and ELOVL7, are known to be involved in the elongation of very long-chain fatty acids. SCD5 and SCD are stearoyl-CoA desaturases, enzymes that introduce double bonds into saturated fatty acids. The metabolic pathway identified in this experiment is Biotin metabolism. The list of altered genes, OXSM and HLCS, are directly involved in this pathway. OXSM, or 3-methylcrotonyl-CoA carboxylase alpha chain, is an enzyme that catalyzes the carboxylation of 3-methylcrotonyl-CoA to 3-methylglutaconyl-CoA in the leucine degradation pathway, which requires biotin as a cofactor. HLCS, or holocarboxylase synthetase, is an enzyme responsible for the attachment of biotin to specific carboxylases, including OXSM, which is essential for their activity.

The altered compounds also support the involvement of Biotin metabolism. These compounds include various forms of biotin (Biotinyl-CoA, Biotin, Biotin sulfoxide, Tetranorbiotin, Dethiobiotin), biotin intermediates (Pimeloyl-[acyl-carrier protein], Long-chain acyl-[acyl-carrier protein], Holo-[carboxylase]), and metabolites involved in biotin-dependent reactions (L-Lysine, Enoylpimeloyl-[acp] methyl ester, Enoylglutaryl-[acp] methyl ester, Malonyl-[acyl-carrier protein]). Therefore, the alterations in these genes and compounds suggest that the Biotin metabolism pathway is significantly affected in the given condition.

The metabolic pathway identified in the experiment is Oxidative Phosphorylation (OXPHOS). This pathway is strongly supported by the altered genes and compounds. The genes NDUFA2, NDUFA8, NDUFB8, NDUFS1, MT-ND4L, MT-ND5 are part of the Complex I of the electron transport chain in OXPHOS. COX10, COX4I1, COX6A1 are components of Complex IV, also involved in OXPHOS. ATP6V1D is involved in ATP synthesis, a key product of OXPHOS. SDHC is a subunit of Complex II, which feeds electrons into the electron transport chain. The compounds Fumarate, Oxygen, H2O, Diphosphate are all involved in OXPHOS. Oxygen is the final electron acceptor, H2O is a product, Diphosphate is converted to ATP, and Fumarate can feed into the TCA cycle which provides NADH and FADH2 for OXPHOS. The H+ ions are involved in the creation of the proton motive force, which drives ATP synthesis. Therefore, the data strongly suggests that Oxidative Phosphorylation is the affected metabolic pathway.

The compounds identified - [Protein]-L-serine, Dolichyl phosphate D-mannose, O-Mannose core M1, O-mannose core M3, CDP-ribitol, O-Mannose core M2, and Phospho-core M3 - are all intermediates or products in the Mannose type O-glycan biosynthesis pathway. The genes SDS (Serine Dehydratase), SDSL (Serine Dehydratase-Like), and BCAT1 (Branched-Chain Aminotransferase 1) are all directly involved in this pathway. The analysis of the provided gene list and associated compounds indicates a strong association with the Pentose Phosphate Pathway (PPP). This pathway is involved in the biosynthesis of nucleotides and aromatic amino acids, and in the production of NADPH for various biosynthetic reactions.

Several genes in the list, such as G6PD, H6PD, PGD, RPE, RPIA, TKT, and TKTL1/2, are directly involved in the PPP. The altered compounds, including D-Glucose 6-phosphate, 6-Phospho-D-gluconate, D-Ribose 5-phosphate, D-Xylulose 5-phosphate, and Sedoheptulose, are intermediates in this pathway, further supporting this conclusion. The involvement of other genes like ALDOA, ALDOC, and PGM1, which are part of glycolysis, suggests a possible interplay between glycolysis and the PPP in this specific condition.

The one carbon pool by folate pathway was identified as the metabolic pathway of interest in this experiment, based on the alterations observed in the genes and compounds. The genes MTHFS and ALDH1L1, which are involved in this pathway, were found to be affected. MTHFS encodes an enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of 5-formiminotetrahydrofolate to 5,10-methylenetetrahydrofolate, while ALDH1L1 encodes an enzyme that converts 10-formyltetrahydrofolate to tetrahydrofolate. The altered compounds, including 5-formiminotetrahydrofolate, 5,10-methylenetetrahydrofolate, folate, dihydrofolate, and 5-methyltetrahydrofolate, are all intermediates or cofactors in this pathway. Therefore, the changes in these genes and compounds suggest that the one carbon pool by folate pathway is disrupted in the condition being studied.

The metabolic pathway identified in this experiment is Glycosaminoglycan (GAG) degradation. This conclusion is supported by the altered genes and compounds observed. The genes HYAL1, HYAL2, HYAL3, and HYAL4 are hyaluronidases, enzymes responsible for degrading hyaluronic acid, a type of GAG. GUSB, IDS, ARSB, and HEXB are lysosomal enzymes involved in the degradation of various GAGs. GNS, SPAM1, HGSNAT, and NAGLU are involved in the synthesis and modification of GAGs, suggesting a potential feedback mechanism in response to altered GAG levels. The compounds Chondroitin 4-sulfate, Dermatan sulfate, and Hyaluronic acid are all GAGs, further supporting the identification of this pathway. The presence of DWA-2, a compound used in the study of GAG degradation, further strengthens this conclusion.

The metabolic pathway identified in the experiment is oxidative phosphorylation. This pathway was implicated due to the significant alterations observed in multiple genes associated with it. These genes include NDUFA7, NDUFA13, NDUFA4, NDUFA1, NDUFV2, MT-ND3, MT-ND4, MT-ATP6, MT-ATP8, ATP5MC1, ATP5MC3, ATP6V1B1, ATP6V0E1, ATP6V1F, ATP6V0B, ATP5ME, COX7A2L, and COX6A1. These genes encode subunits of complexes I, III, IV, and V of the electron transport chain, and the ATP synthase, all of which are crucial components of oxidative phosphorylation. The altered compounds, fumarate and diphosphate, also support this conclusion. Fumarate is a key intermediate in the citric acid cycle, which feeds electrons into the electron transport chain for oxidative phosphorylation. Diphosphate is a byproduct of ATP synthesis in oxidative phosphorylation. The presence of H+ ions further indicates proton gradient changes, a fundamental process in this pathway. Therefore, the data suggest a significant role of oxidative phosphorylation in the observed condition.

The metabolic pathway identified in this experiment is the Pantothenate and CoA biosynthesis pathway. This pathway was implicated due to the alterations in several genes directly involved in its regulation. These genes include PANK1, which encodes pantothenate kinase 1 responsible for the first step in CoA biosynthesis, COASY, which encodes CoA synthase involved in the last step of CoA biosynthesis, and PPCDC, which encodes phosphopantothenoylcysteine decarboxylase, another key enzyme in this pathway. The alteration in the levels of (R)-Pantoate, a precursor in CoA biosynthesis, and Acyl-carrier protein, a protein that carries the growing fatty acid chain during fatty acid biosynthesis which requires CoA, further supports the involvement of this pathway. The altered genes and compounds suggest a potential disruption in the Pantothenate and CoA biosynthesis pathway, which could impact various cellular processes dependent on CoA, such as fatty acid synthesis and energy production.

The altered genes in this experiment, including GALNTL6, GALNT1, GALNTL5, ST6GALNAC2, GALNT5, B3GNT6, GALNT11, ST6GALNAC1, C1GALT1C1, GALNT7, and GCNT4, are all involved in the initiation and elongation steps of O-glycan biosynthesis. The presence of the Tn antigen and its sialylated form, Sialyl-Tn antigen, suggests truncation or aberrant glycosylation in the pathway, which fits with the alterations in the genes involved in this pathway.

The metabolic pathway identified in this experiment is the Glyoxylate and dicarboxylate metabolism. This pathway was implicated due to the alterations observed in several genes and compounds associated with it. The genes HOGA1, HAO2, HAO1, MMUT, AGXT, DLD, and CAT are directly involved in this pathway, which involves the conversion of isocitrate to succinate, bypassing the citrate synthase (CS) and alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase reactions of the citric acid cycle. The altered compounds, such as Acetyl-CoA, (S)-Malate, Formyl-CoA, and D-Ribulose 1-phosphate, are intermediates or substrates in this pathway, further supporting its involvement. The Glyoxylate and dicarboxylate metabolism is particularly active in conditions where carbohydrates are scarce and lipids are the primary source of carbon, which may be the case in the specific conditions compared in this experiment.

The genes ADH6, ADH5, and ADH7 encode for alcohol dehydrogenases, which are involved in the interconversion of alcohols and aldehydes. G6PC1 and GPI are involved in glucose metabolism. The metabolic pathway identified in this experiment is the Vitamin B6 metabolism. PHOSPHO2 encodes an enzyme that converts pyridoxine to pyridoxal phosphate, the active form of Vitamin B6. PNPO is involved in the conversion of pyridoxamine phosphate to pyridoxal phosphate. PDXK is responsible for the phosphorylation of pyridoxine and pyridoxal to their respective phosphate forms. AOX1 encodes an aldehyde oxidase that can oxidize pyridoxal to pyridoxate. The genes listed, such as NDUFA5, NDUFB7, NDUFS6, and NDUFA12, are subunits of Complex I in the electron transport chain, a crucial component of Oxidative Phosphorylation. The compounds H+, NAD+, ADP, ATP, and Oxygen are all key players in Oxidative Phosphorylation, where protons (H+) are pumped across a membrane to generate a proton motive force, which is then used to synthesize ATP from ADP and inorganic phosphate. The presence of Fumarate, a TCA cycle intermediate, suggests a link between this pathway and the Krebs cycle, which feeds into Oxidative Phosphorylation.

On the other hand, PCYT1A is a key enzyme in the Kennedy pathway, which is responsible for the biosynthesis of phospholipids. However, it's not directly involved in phosphonate metabolism, but changes in its activity can indirectly affect the pathway.

The significant alterations in the compounds such as N-Acetyldemethylphosphinothricin tripeptide, 2-Oxo-4-phosphonobutanoate, alpha-D-Ribose 1-methylphosphonate 5-triphosphate, and Methylphosphonate, among others, are key components of the Phosphonate and Phosphinate Metabolism pathway, further supporting the identification of this pathway.

The metabolic pathway identified in the experiment is the Arachidonic Acid Metabolism pathway. This pathway was selected based on the alterations observed in multiple genes and compounds associated with this metabolic process. The genes ALOX5, PTGR1, PLA2G4C, PTGES3, LTA4H, PLA2G3, PLA2G4F, CYP2C9, CYP4F3, AKR1C3, CBR1, and PTGR2 are all involved in the metabolism of arachidonic acid. Similarly, the identified compounds, such as Prostaglandin J2, 11H-14,15-EETA, 2,3-Dinor-8-iso prostaglandin F2alpha, 8(S)-HETE, (5Z)-11alpha-Hydroxy-9,15-dioxoprostanoate, 15-Keto-prostaglandin F2alpha, 5,6-DHET, and Leukotriene F4, are known metabolites of arachidonic acid. Therefore, the changes observed in these genes and compounds suggest that the Arachidonic Acid Metabolism pathway is likely involved in the specific condition being studied.

The metabolic pathway identified in the experiment is the Thiamine metabolism pathway. This pathway was implicated due to the alterations in multiple genes and compounds directly involved in thiamine metabolism. The genes ALPG, AK2, and AK1 were found to be altered, and these genes have been previously associated with thiamine metabolism. Additionally, the altered compounds including Thiamin diphosphate, Thiamine acetic acid, and Pyridoxal phosphate are key intermediates in the Thiamine metabolism pathway. The presence of 4-Methyl-5-(2-phosphooxyethyl)thiazole, 4-Amino-2-methyl-5-(phosphooxymethyl)pyrimidine, and 5-(2-Hydroxyethyl)-4-methylthiazole, which are precursors in the synthesis of Thiamin diphosphate, further supports the involvement of the Thiamine metabolism pathway. Moreover, the presence of Thiocarboxy-[sulfur-carrier protein], a protein involved in the activation of thiamine, and NAD+, a co-enzyme in thiamine metabolism, also suggests the role of this pathway. Thus, the alterations in these genes and compounds indicate that the Thiamine metabolism pathway is likely involved in the specific condition.

The metabolic pathway identified in this experiment is the "Biosynthesis of unsaturated fatty acids." This conclusion is supported by the altered genes and compounds observed. The genes ACAA1, SCP2, ACOT1, HACD3, and TECR are all known to be involved in this pathway. They play roles in various steps such as fatty acid activation, elongation, desaturation, and oxidation. The list of compounds, which includes various unsaturated fatty acids and their corresponding CoA derivatives, further corroborates this finding. These compounds are intermediates and products in the biosynthesis of unsaturated fatty acids pathway. Therefore, the alterations in these genes and compounds suggest that this pathway is significantly affected in the condition being studied.
